channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: OK, is Martin Van Buren responsible for the tiny word that punches above its weight?
item.description: From Buenos Aires to Bangkok, Montreal to Moscow, nearly every taxi driver in the world understands "OK." It's a gift from American English that's spread across the globe in less than 200 years.

item.title: Supreme Court allows Trump to fire 3 Democrats on consumer safety panel
item.description: The decision further limits a 90-year-old high-court precedent that was aimed at protecting the independence of certain regulatory agencies.

item.title: A carbohydrate revolution is fueling cyclists in the Tour de France
item.description: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly speaks with Tim Podlogar, who researches exercise metabolism, about how elite cyclists consume thousands of calories each day to compete in the Tour de France.

item.title: Health experts say older adults should have a go bag for medical emergencies
item.description: A pharmacist created a hospital go-bag for his 93-year-old father. The idea is catching on, since nearly a quarter of older people who go to the emergency department end up being admitted.

item.title: As President Subianto, Trump tout trade deal, Indonesian businesses aren't convinced
item.description: Despite great fanfare in Washington, Indonesian businesses say they are not convinced by the trade agreement with the U.S.

item.title: Mercy Corps official warns of 'mass starvation' in Gaza
item.description: NPR's Ari Shapiro speaks with Kate Phillips-Barrasso, a vice president of Mercy Corps, about a joint statement issued by over 100 aid organizations warning of mass starvation in Gaza.

item.title: What does PEPFAR's future look like?
item.description: When Congress approved a Trump administration plan to take back $9 billion in funds they'd previously allocated to public media and foreign aid, there was just one program that lawmakers decided to spare: The U.S.'s HIV/AIDS initiative or PEPFAR. Does that mean PEPFAR will return to its original role leading the world's HIV/AIDS response? Radio ran on ATC on Wednesday. DIgital for Thursday, hope to publish by 2 p.m.

item.title: Israel's representative to the U.N. faces questions about aid to Gaza
item.description: As the situation in Gaza becomes more and more dire, with reports of people dying from starvation, NPR's Ari Shapiro speaks with Israel's Permanent Representative to the U.N. Danny Danon.

item.title: After massive protests, Ukraine's president reconsiders new anti-corruption law
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelenskyy says he will heed protesters angry about his new anti-corruption policy.

item.title: Why bird feathers are so bright
item.description: Why are some songbirds so brightly colored? A new study finds that a hidden layer of black and white feathers help their colors pop.
